repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Tsunami Emergency Recovery
            Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Tsunami Emergency
            Recovery Program Project for Sri Lanka were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: flexibility of
            project design, particularly in emergency operations
            facilitates implementation and provides a greater
            opportunity for achieving project objectives. Training,
            continuous social mobilization, and effective strategic
            communications are critical for the success of projects and
            consolidation of gains. Development of operational manuals
            and their official notification by the government and
            implementing agency clarifies the roles and responsibilities
            of multiple players and partners involved in the program and
            facilitate smooth implementation. Effective planning in the
            areas of logistics and material supply play a vital role in
            the success of emergency response and reconstruction
            projects. Third-party technical audits, independent
            financial audits, and eligibility surveys in addition to
            existing government mechanisms are good tools for reducing
            the risks associated with governance issues and increase the
            transparency and credibility of program. The home owner
            driven approach with necessary technical assistance allows
            affected communities to develop ownership of the program and
            yields results. In the case of emergency operations, the
            effects of the disaster on government and implementing
            agencies with respect to their capacities should not be
            underestimated and project targets and implementation period
            should be planned and designed accordingly. Joint strategic
            planning and coordination amongst different donors,
            especially after disasters, allows for a more effective
            response through avoiding overlaps and addressing priority
            areas to the benefit of the country and its affected
            population. Effective grievance redressal mechanisms and
            documentation are essential for addressing the concerns and
            issues of beneficiaries and allowing for smooth
            implementation of the program. An effective reporting,
            monitoring and evaluation system is essential for enabling
            informed decision making at both policy and operational levels.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Tsunami Emergency Recovery
            Program - Second Phase

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tsunami Emergency Recovery Program
            for Sri Lange aims to support the efforts of the Government
            of Sri Lanka to: (i) Reduce the immediate suffering
            resulting from the effects of the tsunami and restore
            livelihoods destroyed by the tsunami; (ii) Restore basic
            services to the affected population; and (iii) Start the
            recovery and reconstruction process. IDA carried out a
            portfolio restructuring to release up to US$50 million and
            provisionally set aside US$25 million to provide immediate
            financing for urgent tsunami-related reconstruction efforts.
            This proposed follow-up operation for the Tsunami Emergency
            Recovery Operation, Phase II will continue the financing
            initiated under the Phase I restructuring. It is anticipated
            that other donors would be identified in the near future to
            support some of these priority needs. If other donors were
            to provide grant funds to finance any activity earmarked for
            support by IDA credits, IDA resources will not be used.
